docs.lead_paragraph: A new anxiety is gripping Russia: if its athletes perform as badly as they did in the Vancouver Winter Olympics, the country could be humiliated at home in Sochi in 2014.

headline.main: Its Sports Empire Crumbling, Russia Scrambles
headline.print_headline: Its Sports Empire Crumbling, Russia Scrambles to Avoid Olympic Shame as 2014 Host

docs.snippet: A new anxiety is gripping Russia: if its athletes perform as badly as they did in the Vancouver Winter Olympics, the country could be humiliated at home in Sochi in 2014.

docs.lead_paragraph: POLLITT--Daniel Hubbard, 88, Graham Kenan Professor of Law emeritus, UNC-Chapel Hill, a beloved professor of constitutional and labor law at UNC since 1957. Born July 6, 1921, Washington, DC died March 5, 2010, Chapel Hill. Wesleylan University, Conn., 1943, WWII 2nd Lt. Marine, Pacific theater (two purple hearts), Cornell Law School, 1949. Legal scholar and progressive activist, Dan devoted his life to, and was honored many times for, confronting the major social issues of his time: labor, prisoner, women's rights; civil liberties; racial equality; death penalty; and peace. State and national Board member of ACLU, RAFI-USA, AAUP; chaired the 1974 Citizen's Investigation into the Harlan, KY Coal Strike. Dan clerked with Judge Henry Edgerton, D.C. Court of Appeals, then joined civil rights firm of Joseph Rauh in Washington, DC where he worked on high-profile cases during the anti-Communist witch hunts (Lillian Hellman and Arthur Miller). Dan assisted UNC Basketball Coach Dean Smith in recruiting Charlie Scott, the first African American scholarship athlete at UNC. Dan worked with Rep. Frank Thompson and the U.S. House Subcomm. on Education and Labor during passage of the Pregnancy Disc. Act, Title IX. Predeceased by his wife Jean Ann Rutledge, daughter of Justice Wiley Rutledge, and brother Basil Pollitt. Survived by wife Eleanor Kinnaird, children Daniel R., Phoebe and Susan, sister Betty Kenney, five grandsons, thirteen nieces and nephews, in-laws Neal Rutledge, wife Caroline, Mary-Lou and Ted Needels. "To avoid criticism, do nothing, say nothing, and be nothing."

docs.lead_paragraph: Guys, we've got your playbook. All this time, we've been operating under the mistaken assumption that you were choosing to get all belligerent every time our college boyfriend called, or to tune us out as your eyes became glued to the waitress's breasts showcased in a T-shirt two sizes too small. It stood to reason, we thought, that you could simply choose otherwise, provided, of course, that you wanted to. Now, however, thanks to Louann Brizendine, M.D., author of ''The Male Brain'' (Broadway Books), we understand that choosing otherwise isn't an option, because evolution has outfitted you with a brain that is, biologically speaking, not the same model as the one we were issued. (Brizendine's ''Female Brain'' was published in 2006, should you ever get the urge to consult it.) The epic bouts of road rage, the narcolepsy after sex, the fanatical fixation on the Big East standings, the hunger for movies full of gunfire and explosions -- finally, we get it. Brizendine fills us in on the male brain's larger areas devoted to muscular action, aggression and sex, formed before birth and modulated throughout life by an exquisitely calibrated blend of testosterone, Müllerian inhibiting substance, androstenedione, vasopressin and other hormones that alter perceptions and lay the groundwork for specific behaviors.
docs.abstract: Holly Brubach Biblio File reviews Louann Brizendine's new book The Male Brain and The Male Factor: The Unwritten Rules, Misperceptions, and Secret Beliefs of Men in the Workplace by Shaunti Feldhahn; photo (M)

Born July 6, 1921, Washington, DC died March 5, 2010, Chapel Hill. Wesleylan University, Conn., 1943, WWII 2nd Lt. Marine, Pacific theater (two purple hearts), Cornell Law School, 1949. Legal scholar and progressive activist, Dan devoted his life to, and was honored many times for, confronting the major social issues of his time: labor, prisoner, women's rights; civil liberties; racial equality; death penalty; and peace. State and national Board member of ACLU, RAFI-USA, AAUP; chaired the 1974 Citizen's Investigation into the Harlan, KY Coal Strike. Dan clerked with Judge Henry Edgerton, D.C. Court of Appeals, then joined civil rights firm of Joseph Rauh in Washington, DC where he worked on high-profile cases during the anti-Communist witch hunts (Lillian Hellman and Arthur Miller). Dan assisted UNC Basketball Coach Dean Smith in recruiting Charlie Scott, the first African American scholarship athlete at UNC. Dan worked with Rep. Frank Thompson and the U.S. House Subcomm. on Education and Labor during passage of the Pregnancy Disc. Act, Title IX. Predeceased by his wife Jean Ann Rutledge, daughter of Justice Wiley Rutledge, and brother Basil Pollitt. Survived by wife Eleanor Kinnaird, children Daniel R., Phoebe and Susan, sister Betty Kenney, five grandsons, thirteen nieces and nephews, in-laws Neal Rutledge, wife Caroline, Mary-Lou and Ted Needels. "To avoid criticism, do nothing, say nothing, and be nothing."

docs.lead_paragraph: Today is International Women's Day, and in fact the 100th anniversary of International Women's Day. It's a date that is much better known abroad but is beginning to get more traction in the U.S. as well.

headline.main: Three Proven Steps to Advance the World's Women, on International Women's Day

docs.abstract: On the occasion of International Women's Day, here are three interventions that have a good record in improving the lives of women around the world.
